cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as a group of concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. The Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Vertical Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Astral Plane
planes.philosophicalEssence: A realm of thought and dream, where visitors travel as disembodied souls to reach the Outer Planes.

physicalProperties.shape: A great silvery sea with swirling wisps of white and gray streaking among motes of light
physicalProperties.atmosphereNotes: Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst.

temperature.description: Silvery void with no notable temperature extremes described

timeFlow.description: Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst. Githyanki establish outposts on other planes so their children can grow to maturity.

hazards.name: Psychic Wind
hazards.description: A psychic wind is a storm of thought that batters travelers' minds rather than their bodies. The storm is made of lost memories, forgotten ideas, and subconscious fears that went astray in the Astral Plane and conglomerated into this powerful force. A psychic wind is first sensed as a rapid darkening of the silver-gray sky. After 1d4 minutes, the area becomes as dark as a moonless night. As the sky darkens, the traveler feels buffeting and shaking, as if the plane were rebelling against the storm. As quickly as it comes, the psychic wind passes, and the sky returns to normal in 1 minute. A group of travelers journeying together is subjected to one location effect, determined by consulting the Psychic Wind Location Effects table. Each traveler caught in a psychic wind makes a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the traveler suffers a random effect from the Psychic Wind Psychic Effects table as well.

damagePerTurn.frequencyDescription: On failed DC 15 Intelligence saving throw when caught in a psychic wind, if psychic effect roll result is 13-17 on d20
damagePerTurn.triggerCondition: Failed DC 15 Intelligence saving throw while caught in a psychic wind and rolled 13-17 on the Psychic Wind Psychic Effects table

savingThrowForHalf.onFailure: full damage if psychic effect roll indicates damage

savingThrowToTraverse.triggerDescription: Each traveler caught in a psychic wind makes a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw to resist psychic effects. Location effects apply to the entire group regardless of the save.

onFailure.description: On a failed save, the traveler suffers a random effect from the Psychic Wind Psychic Effects table: d20 roll 1-8 results in Stunned condition for 1 minute (repeat save at end of each turn to end), 9-12 results in 11 (2d10) Psychic damage, 13-17 results in 22 (4d10) Psychic damage, 18-20 results in Unconscious condition for 5 (1d10) hours (ends if the creature takes damage or another creature takes an action to shake it awake).

onSuccess.description: On a successful save, the traveler suffers no psychic effect from the Psychic Wind Psychic Effects table. The group-wide location effect from the Psychic Wind Location Effects table still applies.

savingThrowToTraverse.repeatSaveTiming: End of each of the creature's turns (only for the Stunned condition effect, rolls 1-8 on the Psychic Effects table)

detectionMethod.warningDescription: A psychic wind is first sensed as a rapid darkening of the silver-gray sky. After 1d4 minutes (average 2.5), the area becomes as dark as a moonless night.

entries.description: Diverted; add 1d6 days to travel time
Blown astray; add 3d10 days to travel time
Lost; at the end of the travel time, the characters arrive at a location other than the intended destination
Sent through a random color pool (roll on the Astral Color Pools table)

entries.durationDescription: 1 minute; repeat the saving throw at the end of each of your turns, ending the effect on yourself on a success
5 (1d10) hours; the effect ends if you take damage or if another creature takes an action to shake you awake

hazards.sourceReference: Chapter 6: Cosmology, Astral Plane, Psychic Wind

portals.destination: Various Outer Planes, Inner Planes, or Material Plane
portals.colorOrAppearance: Two-dimensional pools of rippling colors, perceived by the Astral self rather than physical eyes

planarConnections.name: Psychic Wind
planarConnections.description: A psychic wind can send travelers through a random color pool, potentially depositing them on any plane reachable via Astral color pools. Roll on the Astral Color Pools table (d20) to determine the destination.

civilizations.name: Githyanki
civilizations.description: Githyanki establish outposts on the Astral Plane, building cities on the petrified corpses of dead gods. Tu'narath is the most infamous such city.
civilizations.location: Various locations including dead god corpses

specialRules.name: Astral Movement
specialRules.description: A traveler in the Astral Plane can move by simply thinking about moving. In combat, a creature has a Fly Speed (in feet) equal to 5 times its Intelligence score and can hover.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Fly Speed = 5 × Intelligence score (in feet). Creature can hover. Outside combat, distance is meaningless and movement is accomplished by thought.

specialRules.name: Astral Navigation
specialRules.description: All that is required to find one's destination is to think about it. As long as the destination is somewhere in the Astral Plane or in Wildspace, thinking about a place makes the creature aware of the most direct route to that location.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Thinking about a destination reveals the most direct route. Travel to a specific location takes 4d6 days; travel to a general location takes 1d4 × 10 hours.

specialRules.name: Astral Timelessness
specialRules.description: Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: No aging, no hunger, no thirst while on the Astral Plane.

planarTravelMethods.name: Astral Projection
planarTravelMethods.description: Astral Projection lets adventurers project themselves into the Astral Plane and from there travel to the Outer Planes.
risks: Encounters with githyanki or other Astral denizens
destinations: Any Outer Plane via color pools

planarTravelMethods.name: Gate
planarTravelMethods.description: Gate can directly transport adventurers to any other plane.

planarTravelMethods.name: Plane Shift
planarTravelMethods.description: Plane Shift can directly transport adventurers to any other plane, with different degrees of precision.
requirements: Tuning fork attuned to destination plane

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
